cmCourseInfo.description: This introductory, foundational course is a survey of Canada's political, social, and economic history with special attention to its evolution as a diverse, multicultural nation from European roots. Other themes focus on Canada's native peoples, regionalism, immigration/migration issues, and Canada’s role on the international stage, especially relations with Britain and the United States. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian History (formerly JWH100Y1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is available only to students in the Academic Bridging Program. For more information, please contact: Woodsworth College 119 St. George Street, Room 220. For office hours please check the program website. Phone: 416-978-4444 | academic.bridging@utoronto.ca | www.wdw.utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: This interdisciplinary, foundational course provides an introduction to contemporary Canadian society. The course includes the study of geography, politics, literature and culture through a historical framework of the twentieth century. It also emphasizes particular themes including aboriginal issues, Quebec nationalism, gender/women's issues and immigration/multiculturalism. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Canada (formerly JWU100Y1)

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: Introduction to the Study of Literature (formerly ENG185Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This discipline based, writing intensive course introduces essential rhetorical and critical skills, focusing on how to recognize major literary forms and how to read and analyze outstanding classic and contemporary literary works of drama, poetry and fiction. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Study of Literature (formerly ENG185Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This interdisciplinary course introduces the major issues regarding the sustainability of the global environment in the face of human development by integrating humanities and social science with the fundamental concept of environmental science. It examines major environmental problems, such as rapid climate change and land degradation as well as the role and impact of government, economics, and ethics on environmental issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Environmental Studies

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: Topics in Indigenous Cultures and Societies

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an interdisciplinary focus on key topics relevant to Indigenous communities, historically and in the present. Students will be introduced to diverse cultures, communities, and worldviews of Indigenous peoples of Turtle Island (particularly Canada) and how they have been affected by colonialism. Emphasis will be placed on the ways Indigenous peoples are resisting social, economic, political, and environmental injustices, while revitalizing their identities, knowledges, and communities and creating space for the expression of Indigenous voices. Storytelling that prioritizes the perspectives and worldviews of Indigenous peoples will guide students’ learning about course topics, issues, and concepts. Students will be encouraged to connect their own storied identities and perspectives to course themes and issues. Classes will involve a mix of interactive lectures, class discussion, student-led learning opportunities, and field trips. Class time and assignments will also be devoted to helping students build their critical thinking, reading, and writing skills towards the completion of a research-based essay due at the end of the year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Indigenous Cultures and Societies

courses.name: Order and Disorder I: Issues and Perspectives

cmCourseInfo.description: Societies require law and order, but at what point does order become oppression? How do we balance our need for freedom and society’s need for order? This interdisciplinary seminar allows students to explore these and related questions through selected readings introducing theories from sociology, political science, philosophy, and history. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Order and Disorder I: Issues and Perspectives
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI One, MUN One, NEW One, SMC One, TRN One, UNI One, VIC One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
These courses are restricted to first year students (St. George campus) admitted to the Woodsworth One Program. LEC2000 is reserved for students in the full-time Academic Bridging Program. For more information, please contact: 416-946-0605 | one.wdw@utoronto.ca | www.wdw.utoronto.ca

courses.name: Order and Disorder II: Problems and Solutions

cmCourseInfo.description: Building on the questions and theoretical perspectives discussed in WDW151H1, this interdisciplinary seminar introduces students to some of the methods used by scholars and researchers in sociology, political science, philosophy, and history to develop, test, and debate possible solutions to the problems of social order and disorder. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Order and Disorder II: Problems and Solutions
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WDW151H1 or permission of the Woodsworth One Program Coordinator
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI One, MUN One, NEW One, SMC One, TRN One, UNI One, VIC One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
These courses are restricted to first year students (St. George campus) admitted to the Woodsworth One Program. LEC2000 is reserved for students in the full-time Academic Bridging Program. For more information, please contact: 416-946-0605 | one.wdw@utoronto.ca | www.wdw.utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Digital Humanities (DH) studies human culture -- art, literature, history, geography, religion -- using computational tools and methodologies, and at the same time studies digital technologies and communities through humanist lenses, as complex cultural objects shaped by wider social and political concerns and the ways we construct knowledge and meaning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Digital Humanities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4 FCEs at the 100 level, at least 1 FCE of which must be in Humanities

courses.name: Virtual Worlds: Introduction to Spatial Digital Humanities

cmCourseInfo.description: A Digital Humanities perspective on the virtual worlds in which we are increasingly immersed, from scholarly digital archives to video games. We study the theory and methods of geospatial humanities research and explore the technical and cultural implications of computer vision, augmented reality, the Internet of Things, and 3D printing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Virtual Worlds: Introduction to Spatial Digital Humanities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WDW235H1 or permission of the Program Coordinator

courses.name: From Book to Map to Video Game: Texts and their Digital Transformations

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the new forms of storytelling made possible by digital media from two perspectives, that of the maker and that of the scholarly reader. Students learn to critically analyze storytelling in new media and experiment with their own adaptations of a literary text to various digital platforms.
cmCourseInfo.title: From Book to Map to Video Game: Texts and their Digital Transformations
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WDW235H1 and WDW236H1; open to students not taking the Digital Humanities Minor by permission of the program coordinator.

courses.name: Cultural Literacy in the Digital Age

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines two related debates about digital media in education: first, how best to integrate digital technology into learning (digital or computer literacy), and, secondly, what knowledge is required for full cultural participation (cultural literacy). We examine these issues using a range of academic, general interest and discipline-specific sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cultural Literacy in the Digital Age
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WDW235H1 and WDW236H1; open to students not taking the Digital Humanities Minor by permission of the program coordinator.
